, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">NIPT was first\nintroduced clinically in 2011, and has become immensely popular, as it is much\nless invasive in some cases, and more sensitive and specific than currently\navailable tests for prenatal diagnosis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The NIPT (noninvasive\nprenatal testing) is a genetic test performed on pregnant women, in order to\ndetect fetal chromosomal aneuploidies.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is based upon the testing of\ncell-free fetal DNA (cf-fDNA) separated from the blood of the mother. It\nrequires only a simple blood draw and is associated with no serious\ncomplications, like other blood tests.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fetal DNA fragments\nleak into maternal circulation in small amounts during pregnancy from the\namniotic fluid. This can be analyzed, and all the adjoining sequences linked\nup, to map them to the individual chromosomes. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Recently developed\ntechniques such as shotgun massively parallel sequencing (MPS), especially if\ndesigned to target the chromosomes of interest, such as 21 or 18, make it easy,\nfast and inexpensive to sequence and compare fetal and maternal DNA in these\nspecified chromosomal regions. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This helps identify\nexcessive material in the fetal chromosomes and quantify it, to give the risk\nof aneuploidy. In other words, having more of chromosome 21 material than\nexpected signals that the fetus has an extra 21st chromosome.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This test can be done\nby about 10 weeks of gestation, and is highly specific for the current\npregnancy because it is cleared within an hour by the woman\u2019s body. This means\nthat no cell-free fetal DNA can be found more than an hour after delivery of\nthe fetus.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">NIPT test &nbsp;uses amazing technology to isolate fetal DNA\nfrom the mother\u2019s blood and test this for down syndrome. This test is highly\naccurate and it can be performed as early as 9 weeks into the pregnancy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">NIPT has a high\naccuracy of over 98% in detecting a fetus with Down syndrome.&nbsp; Fetal sex and paternity is also detectable at\nan early stage of pregnancy.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The test results may be\none of three types:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Positive, which means\nthe child will almost certainly have Down syndrome; invasive testing is offered\nto confirm this.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Negative, which is\ninterpreted to mean the fetus is very unlikely to have Down syndrome<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Inconclusive, which\nmeans no conclusions could be drawn because there was too little cf-fDNA to be\ntested. The NIPT test may be repeated a little later, when more cf-fDNA is\nlikely to be present. This makes up about 4% of cases.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Also known as cell-free\nDNA screening, non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a blood test that looks\nat the DNA in your baby\u2019s placenta to determine if there is an increased risk\nof you giving birth to a child with a genetic disorder.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The advantage of NIPT\nover other tests is that it can be done early during pregnancy and is accurate\ncompared to other screening tests. It is also more sensitive and specific than\nquite a few other first and second trimester screenings.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">NIPT is helpful in\ndetecting Down\u2019s Syndrome, Edward\u2019s Syndrome, and Patau Syndrome, also known as\nTrisomy 21, Trisomy 18, and Trisomy 13, respectively. It can also pinpoint the\nbaby\u2019s gender and Rh blood type.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This test is done when\nyou are ten weeks pregnant or later and the results are known in about two\nweeks. &nbsp;In Indian we don\u2019t have too many\nfacilities and usually the samples go abroad.. It is not recommended for cases\nwhere fetal anomalies can be spotted on an ultrasound or for genetic anomalies\nthat will not be detected by NIPT.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In both these tests, a\nsample of maternal blood is taken for analysis. While NIPT looks at the\ncell-free DNA in the mother\u2019s blood, the combined and quadruple test check\u2019s\nthe mother\u2019s hormone levels. Given its accuracy rates, NIPT is considered a\nbetter tool for evaluating the chances of the baby having Down\u2019s syndrome&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/uiQlLfWClqA/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/uiQlLfWClqA?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Causes of False\nPositives:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This might happen due\nto \u2018vanishing twin syndrome\u2019, and a scan can help determine if this is the\ncase. A false positive might also be due to some problem present in the mother\nrather than the baby or caused by the presence of an abnormal cell line in the\nplacenta but not in the baby.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Causes of False\nNegatives:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the amount of foetal\nDNA present in the sample is too little, it can result in a false negative. An\nabnormal cell line that is present only in the baby, not in the placenta, can\nresult in a false negative. Technical issues can also give a false negative.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Also, when the mother\nis carrying twins or multiples, the result of NIPT may not be clear cut because\nit can be difficult to know which of the foetuses is affected without an\nindividual amniocentesis for each.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Only about 4 % of all\nNIPT tests turn out to be inconclusive. This might happen when there is a low\namount of foetal DNA present in the sample. The NIPT might have to be repeated.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/HuVlJI4NLwc/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/HuVlJI4NLwc?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Harmony test, like\nother NIPT products on the market, is a screening test, not a diagnostic one.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Harmony test, is a\nblood test for pregnant women. It can be done as early as week 10 of your\npregnancy. It picks up a marker of the baby\u2019s DNA in maternal blood. That\nreading, based on cell-free genetic analysis, can give a probability score (not\na diagnosis) for at least three chromosomal anomalies in the baby\u2019s genes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Harmony test is\nmore than 99% predictive of the risk of Down\u2019s syndrome (trisomy 21). It\u2019s also\nmore than 98% predictive of the risk of Edwards\u2019 syndrome (trisomy 18) and 80%\npredictive of the risk of Patau\u2019s syndrome (trisomy 13).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">High-risk patients then\nneed to have a CVS or amniocentesis, both highly invasive tests, to confirm the\ndiagnosis. 1 in 100 of them will miscarry the baby as a result of either test. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Little wonder that\nnon-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT), of which the Harmony test is one of\nseveral products, came along. It\u2019s expensive:. A low-risk score means you won\u2019t\nhave to undergo that stressful and risky invasive testing. NIPT can also tell\nyou if you\u2019re having a boy or a girl.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">NIPT is based on\nlooking at genetic material that comes directly from the baby. During\npregnancy, some of the baby\u2019s DNA crosses into the mother\u2019s blood stream. DNA\ncarries genetic information on chromosomes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The DNA mainly comes from cells\nshed from the placenta which, as the placenta is formed from the same original\ncells as the baby, is the same as the baby\u2019s DNA. This DNA is called \u201cFree\nFetal DNA (fFDNA)\u201d. Free fetal DNA can be isolated from the mothers blood by\nthe ninth week of pregnancy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">NIPT a very good\nscreening test but it is not 100%. This means that if the test result is \u201chigh\nrisk\u201d it still needs to be checked using an invasive test (either CVS or\namniocentesis).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the NIPT blood test\nis taken at 11weeks, the result is usually available in 3-5 days which is in\ntime for CVS to be performed at 12-13 weeks if needed.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The system of\ntraditional first-trimester screening (the nuchal fold and blood screen) has\nalways had its flaws. What the new NIPT screening process has done is highlight\nthose flaws and exacerbate them.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The only way to be\ncertain that a baby does or does not have Down syndrome is to check the genetic\ninformation within cells from the baby or the placenta. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When screening tests\npredict a high risk of Down syndrome, a more invasive diagnostic test\n(amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling) is needed to confirm the\ndiagnosis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Currently the most\naccurate way to do this is by either an amniocentesis, which is when a needle\nis used to collect some amniotic fluid from around the baby (which has fetal\ncells floating in it), or by a chorionic villous sampling ( CVS) when the\nneedle collects some placental tissue (which develops from the same cells as the\nbaby). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because these tests\nboth involve passing a needle into the uterus they are commonly called\n\u201cinvasive tests\u201d.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again, both tests\ninvolve passing a needle through your abdomen into the uterus. &nbsp;They are invasive tests and involve extracting\ncells from the fetus and analyzing them under a microscope<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Although uncomfortable, most women do not find\nthem more uncomfortable than a blood test.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Then geneticists can\ndetermine whether the fetus has too few or too many chromosomes present, or if\nthe chromosomes are damaged and could result in a genetic problem.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The test performed on\nCVS or amniocentesis examine all the baby\u2019s chromosomes at a microscopic level.\nIt will confirm if Down syndrome is present (or not) very accurately. Because\nall the chromosomes are checked, sometimes other unexpected results are found\nas well.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The most important risk\nassociated with CVS and amniocentesis is the risk of pregnancy loss\n(miscarriage). This is reported to occur approximately once in every 150 to 200\nprocedures, and is roughly the same for both CVS and amniocentesis.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The most\nusual way for pregnancy loss to occur is after rupture of the membranes or\ninfection. It is important to be aware that pregnancy loss can occur even if\nthe procedure appears to have been uncomplicated.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Amniocentesis is\nconsidered the gold standard for prenatal genetic testing.. &nbsp;&nbsp;Amniocentesis\nis performed from 16 weeks and involves taking a sample of the amniotic fluid.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">How it's done: A long,\nthin needle is inserted into the mother's abdomen to obtain a sample of the\namniotic fluid surrounding the fetus. &nbsp;The\namniotic fluid contains cells from the fetus with genetic information about the\nunborn child.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The fetus' chromosomes\ncan be analyzed, looking for trisomy 21.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chorionic villus\nsampling (CVS) \u2013 is performed between 11-14 weeks . CVS&nbsp; diagnostic test involves taking a small\nsample of cells from the placenta for fetal chromosome analysis<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Placental tissue\ncontains the same genetic material as the fetus and can be checked for\nchromosomal abnormalities and other genetic disorders. However, CVS cannot\nidentify neural tube defects, such as spina bifida, which can be detected by\namniocentesis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/07/myelomeningocele-spina-bifida-neural.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/07/myelomeningocele-spina-bifida-neural.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Depending upon where\nthe placenta is located and using ultrasound for guidance, a small tube is\ninserted through either the mother's abdomen or her vagina and a small tissue\nsample is withdrawn from the placenta.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CVS has a slightly\nhigher risk of miscarriage than amniocentesis. CVS has a 1 percent risk of\nmiscarriage</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again,&nbsp; CVS is done between 11-14 weeks and\namniocentesis is done from 15-16 weeks of pregnancy. &nbsp;&nbsp;While these tests will give definite answers,\nthey carry with them a small risk of complication, including miscarriage, of\napproximately 1 in 150- 200.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Screening tests\nevaluate the degree of risk, or chance, that the fetus may potentially have\ncertain common birth defects. &nbsp;&nbsp;But they\ncannot tell with certainty if the baby actually has the problem<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">First trimester\nscreening tests are usually done between the 10th and 13th weeks of pregnancy.\nOne common screening test measures the level of certain substances in the\nmother's blood to assess the risk for Down syndrome and other chromosomal\nproblems.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Another first trimester screening test, known\nas \"nuchal translucency,\" uses ultrasound to examine the area at the\nback of the fetus's neck for increased fluid or thickening, which may indicate\na potential risk for Down syndrome.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Combined First\nTrimester Screening Test (CFTS) is made up of a blood test, an ultrasound and\nthe egg age. The blood test measures the hormones PAPP-A and HCG. It needs to\nbe done between 9 and 12 weeks (10 weeks is the best time). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ultrasound measures\nthe length of the baby, the back of the baby\u2019s neck (nuchal translucency), the\nnasal bone and the blood flow in baby\u2019s blood vessels. It needs to be done\nbetween 11+3 weeks and 13+6 weeks. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The egg age is usually\nthe mothers age unless the pregnancy is following IVF. The blood test results\nare held in the lab until the scan is completed, and then the results are\ncombined, so you receive one result only.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The CFTS puts\ninformation from your pregnancy into a mathematical formula : Down syndrome\nrisk = blood hormones( 10 weeks) + ultrasound ( 12 weeks) + egg age<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Your test result is\ncompared to that expected in a normal pregnancy and in a Down syndrome\npregnancy and then your baby is characterized as either more likely to be a\nnormal or more likely to have Down syndrome.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The result is given as\na \u201crisk \u201dnumber. By convention, any result that is \u201cworse\u201d than 1 in 300 is\nclassified as \u201chigh risk\u201d (eg 1 in 100, 1 in 50, etc) and any result that is\n\u201cbetter\u201d than 1 in 300 is classified as \u201clow risk (eg 1 in 500, 1 in 1,000\netc)\u201d.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">95% of women having\nCFTS will be given a \u201clow risk\u201d result and while the risk of having a baby\naffected by Down syndrome is very low, it is never zero, and very rarely a baby\nwill be born with Down syndrome following a \u201clow risk\u201d result.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">About 4-5% of women\nscreened with the CFTS will be given a \u201chigh risk\u201d result but most of those\nwomen will in fact not have a baby with Down syndrome.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Comprehensive\nChromosome Screening (CCS) allows us to determine, at the embryo stage, how\nmany chromosomes are present and therefore whether the embryo has the potential\nto make a live birth.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This technology allows us to identify embryos that may be\nable to establish a pregnancy, such as Trisomy 16 or Trisomy 22, however, but\nhave a 0% chance of making a live birth and will always result in miscarriage. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CCS is extremely useful\nfor couples that are at risk of chromosomal problems. The broadest category\nwould be older parents,. It is very clear that older women (and this applies to\nolder men as well although at a lower rate) are at an increased risk for\nmiscarriages and Down's syndrome. CCS allows us to identify which embryos are\nchromosomally abnormal.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CCS allows us to\nexclude abnormal embryos that have no chance of making a healthy baby. This\nwill reduce the number of embryo transfers necessary to find the \u201cright\nembryo.\u201d In this fashion, it will increase the efficiency of the process and\nthe success of in vitro fertilization (IVF).</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Also, since we have\nruled out the abnormal embryos, the embryos which CCS has shown to have a\nnormal number of chromosomes are far more likely to implant. Therefore we can\nremain conservative, and transfer just one embryo at a time, thereby\neliminating the risk of a multiple pregnancy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A screening test will\nhelp identify the possibility of Down syndrome. Screening tests do not provide\nconclusive answers, but rather, they provide an indication of the likelihood of\nthe baby having Down syndrome. An abnormal test result does not mean that your\nbaby has Down syndrome.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: large;\"></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b>WE ASK MODI GOVT<o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b>DO A FRESH CENSUS OF DOWN SYNDROME PATIENTS\nIN INDIA USING AADHAR CARD TRACKING SYSTEM<o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b>WE DON\u2019T WANT BHARATMATA TO GO DOWN THIS EVIL\nPHARMA SPONSORED ROAD<o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b>THE CENSUS MUST HOLD INFORMATION AS TO WHAT\nAGE THE MOTHER CONCEIVED AND THE NAME OF THE DOCTOR/ HOSPITAL/ LAB &nbsp;WHO ALLOWED THE PREGNANCY TO FRUCTIFY<o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b>MIND YOU , WE MUST HAVE CHECKS AND BALANCES</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/cMtkoTRJp7E/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/cMtkoTRJp7E?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">It is possible to avoid\nconceiving a child with potentially debilitating genetic diseases by opting for\n</span><span style=\"color: red;\">preimplantation genetic screening (PGS) </span><span style=\"color: blue;\">before the embryo is implanted.</span></b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-bMvCupsUjwY/Wryi8mrIMAI/AAAAAAABaAA/DyfHRYP12QAR0PAH3veNizacZlNPXWASACLcBGAs/s1600/HSSow-PGS-Works-1.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"524\" data-original-width=\"621\" height=\"540\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-bMvCupsUjwY/Wryi8mrIMAI/AAAAAAABaAA/DyfHRYP12QAR0PAH3veNizacZlNPXWASACLcBGAs/s640/HSSow-PGS-Works-1.png\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Preimplantation genetic screening (PGS) and\npreimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) are extra stages of the procedure that\npatients are able to opt for if they are worried that there may be factors that\nmight prevent them from conceiving without complications.&nbsp; It must be made compulsory for women above 34\nyears of age going for IVF.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">PGS and PGD are\nadditional services will offer peace of mind to those wanting to rule out\nproblems. Both processes are carried out on fertilised eggs, or \u201cpre-embryos\u201d.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">PGS accuracy is\napproximately 98-99% however ante- natal screening may be recommended in\naddition.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-RCTO8QSEgBw/Wryijp719-I/AAAAAAABZ_8/icKp7V358KczEApICivX6FirXgjuS1N_ACLcBGAs/s1600/reSSducing-risk-in-the-pgd-process-from-ivf-lab-to-genetics-lab-1-638.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"479\" data-original-width=\"638\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-RCTO8QSEgBw/Wryijp719-I/AAAAAAABZ_8/icKp7V358KczEApICivX6FirXgjuS1N_ACLcBGAs/s640/reSSducing-risk-in-the-pgd-process-from-ivf-lab-to-genetics-lab-1-638.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is a slight\ndifference between PGS and PGD:&nbsp;&nbsp; PGS\nscreens for any chromosomal abnormalities that may be present, while PGD looks\nout for something specific. If one or both of the parents are at risk of a\nparticular chromosomal abnormality, PGD may be the right choice. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Fcxugd65EEQ/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Fcxugd65EEQ?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Among the best known\nchromosomal abnormalities that may be identified by combining PGS and IVF are\nDown\u2019s syndrome, muscular dystrophy and Huntington\u2019s disease, though this is\nnot a definitive list.. .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Fcxugd65EEQ/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Fcxugd65EEQ?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">In both PGS and PGD procedures, eggs are\nharvested from the female patient and fertilised. Otherwise, the IVF procedure\nis exactly the same as usual. As the testing is carried out on the fertilised\negg, neither PGS nor PGD are painful..&nbsp;</span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/1S46487uITk/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/1S46487uITk?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Over the previous decade preimplantation\ngenetic screening has become increasingly comprehensive, from being able to\ninspect just 9 chromosomal pairs in 2006 to being able to investigate all 23\npairs in 2018.</span></span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ItHfD5QTlaU/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ItHfD5QTlaU?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">PGS works by looking at\nthe amount of genetic material within IVF embryos. This genetic material is\nhoused within structures called chromosomes. Chromosomes are very important for\nhealthy growth and development.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">PGS identifies embryos with the correct number\nof chromosomes, so your care team can select the embryo with the best chance of\nleading to IVF success. or each embryo tested, PGS results will fall into one\nof three categories: euploid, aneuploid, or mosaic. This information can help\nyour care team select the best embryo for transfer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Embryos are produced\nthrough an IVF cycle. A few cells are carefully removed from the part of the\nembryo that will form the placenta. Samples are sent to the laboratory while\nyour embryos remain safe at your IVF center.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Genomics Labs uses cutting-edge\ntechnology to analyze the genetic material present within each embryo. Embryos\nmost likely to result in success are selected for transfer or can be frozen for\nfuture use.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All women are at risk\nof producing chromosomally abnormal embryos. As a woman ages, the potential for\nchromosomally abnormal embryos significantly increases, regardless of the\nnumber of embryos produced.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">PGS can help women of\nall ages increase their chances of a successful pregnancy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-i3Jj9GPHgOM/WrylGNEXR8I/AAAAAAABaAQ/ZrSFnFsGMc4Sdd2MpwzXi3WscWdeARwbQCLcBGAs/s1600/pgd-chromosoWme-numbers.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"416\" data-original-width=\"776\" height=\"342\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-i3Jj9GPHgOM/WrylGNEXR8I/AAAAAAABaAQ/ZrSFnFsGMc4Sdd2MpwzXi3WscWdeARwbQCLcBGAs/s640/pgd-chromosoWme-numbers.png\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Preimplantation genetic\nscreening (PGS) is a test that determines if an embryo has a normal number of\nchromosomes (euploid) or an abnormal number of chromosomes (aneuploid).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This\ntest allows us to select only chromosomally normal embryos for transfer;\nhowever, transferring a \u2018normal\u2019 embryo does not guarantee a pregnancy, nor\ndoes it guarantee a healthy baby should a pregnancy make it to term.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\npurpose of PGS is to exclude chromosomally abnormal embryos from the transfer\nprocess.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">WE MUST MAKE PGS FREE\nIN INDIA FOR WOMEN OVER THE AGE OF 34.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-pTdP-AIeBXA/WrymcG-AVmI/AAAAAAABaAg/S_eedewBfuMmgdPAPWM2GbtgAm_o6L2iwCLcBGAs/s1600/DSWhR87XU8AAC4tk.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"407\" data-original-width=\"738\" height=\"352\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-pTdP-AIeBXA/WrymcG-AVmI/AAAAAAABaAg/S_eedewBfuMmgdPAPWM2GbtgAm_o6L2iwCLcBGAs/s640/DSWhR87XU8AAC4tk.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Preimplantation genetic\ndiagnosis (PGD) is a test that determines if an embryo carries a specific gene\nthat is associated with a particular disease.. Both PGS and PGD require an\nembryo biopsy to obtain a sample for testing.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is achieved by lasering a\nsmall hole in the outer layer of the embryo and removing a few cells from the\nembryo.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-VnY36rZ5U2o/WrymNSEvEvI/AAAAAAABaAc/YmvOfxrhD2woorUn9HPRCYa8evvs-kBhQCLcBGAs/s1600/PGSWW-vs-PGD.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Commercial surrogacy in\nIndia was legalized in India in 2002. The availability of medical infrastructure\nand CHEAP potential surrogates, combined with international demand, has fueled\nthe growth of the industry<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The clandestine surrogacy\nbusiness is more than one billion USD a year with more than 4,000 fertility\nclinics across India<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A soon as the child is\nborn the vulnerable Indian surrogate mother is discarded\u2014she is not even paid\nher fees.&nbsp; Many surrogate women die, but\nthere is a mafia hushing this up with bribes to politicians</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">More than 40,000\nchildren are now being born through surrogates in India every year in an\nindustry worth in excess of 3 billion USD.. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Domestic demand is increasing, but as\nfertility levels drop elsewhere, at least 62% of these are\n\"commissioned\" by overseas, mainly western, couples</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most of the industry is\noperating unchecked. India's medical research watchdog drafted regulations more\nthan two years ago, yet they still await presentation in parliament, leaving\nthe surrogates and baby factories open to abuse<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">&nbsp;India is a destination\nfor clandestine surrogacy-related fertility tourism because of the DIRT CHEAP &nbsp;cost and lack of rights for the surrogate\nmother .&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">Including the costs of flight tickets, medical procedures, and hotels,\nit is less than 18% of the price compared with going through the procedure in\nthe West. <sup><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrogacy_laws_by_country#cite_note-kannan-32\"></a></sup>&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">In\nthe case of Balaz v. Union of India the Honorable Supreme Court of India has\ngiven the verdict that the citizenship of the child born through this process\nwill have the citizenship of its surrogate mother. &nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">This made it easy for the white bastards to discard\ntheir malformed babies in India<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Surrogacy is a method\nor agreement whereby a woman agrees to carry a pregnancy for another person or\npersons, who will become the newborn child's parents after birth. If the\nsurrogate receives money for the surrogacy the arrangement is considered\ncommercial surrogacy; if she receives no compensation beyond reimbursement of\nmedical and other reasonable expenses it is referred to as altruistic.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In August 2017 the\nParliamentary Standing Committee submitted its 102nd report on the Surrogacy\nRegulation Bill, 2016.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One of the biggest and\nmost prominent drawbacks is the contradiction in the Bill with respect to\nwhether traditional surrogacy is allowed or gestational surrogacy. Traditional\nsurrogacy is one where the egg of the surrogate mother and the intended\nfather's sperm is used to conceive the child with the help of IVF technology.\nIt is the most widely practised forms of surrogacy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Gestational surrogacy \u2013\nalso referred to as \"full surrogacy\" \u2013 is the case where the egg and\nsperm are of the commissioning parents and the surrogate mother carries the\nfertilised egg of the intended parents.Thus, all of the genetic material\ninvolved originates either from the intended parents or donors.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Surrogacy\nRegulation Bill, 2016, under Section 4 (iii) (b) (III) lays down: \"No\nwomen shall act as a surrogate mother or help in surrogacy in any way, by\nproviding gametes or by carrying the pregnancy, more than once in her lifetime.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The object of the Bill\nis to prevent exploitation, however, this very basic provision if not rectified\ncan lead to the opening of a Pandora's box, especially since the current Bill\nprovides that surrogacy can only be performed by a \"close relative\".\nThe emotional stress and complications of having a close relative as a\nsurrogate, on the life of the surrogate child, surrogate mother and the\ncommissioning parents, is immeasurable.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>Surrogacy\n(Regulation) Bill, 2016</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some\nof the salient features of the proposed Bill are:<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Complete\nban on commercial surrogacy, only altruistic surrogacy will be legal. The Act\ndefines altruistic surrogacy as: \u201caltruistic surrogacy means the surrogacy in\nwhich no charges, expenses, fees, remuneration or monetary incentive of\nwhatever nature, except the medical expenses incurred on surrogate mother and\nthe insurance coverage for the surrogate mother, are given to the surrogate mother\nor her dependents or her representative.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Only\n\u201cinfertile couples\u201d married for at least five years can opt for having a child\nthrough a surrogate mother, the couple must be Indian citizens and should not\nhave any child\u2014biological or adopted\u2014at the time of applying for surrogacy.<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Only\na close relative of the couple can act as a surrogate.<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nsurrogate mother must have an eligibility certificate issued by an appropriate\nauthority, she must be married and have a child of her own and be aged between\n25 to 35 years on the day of implantation.<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Setting\nup of a National Surrogacy Board at the central level along with State\nSurrogacy Boards in states and Union Territories. The National Surrogacy Board\nwill advise the central government on policy matters relating to surrogacy,\nreview and monitor the implementation of the Act, lay down a code of conduct to\nbe observed by persons working at surrogacy clinics, set minimum standards of\nphysical infrastructure, laboratory and diagnostic equipment and expert\nmanpower to be employed by the surrogacy clinics, and so on.<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Stringent\npenalties prescribed<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Offences\nand penalties under the Act:<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Commercial\nsurrogacy, publicising commercial surrogacy or aiding buying or selling of\nhuman embryo or gametes will be punishable with imprisonment for a minimum term\nof 10 years and with fine of up to Rs 10 lakh.<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Registered\nmedical practitioners, gynaecologists, paediatricians or surrogacy clinic\nowners who contravene any provision of the Act shall be punishable with\nimprisonment of up to five years and with fine of up to Rs 10 lakh. In case of\nsubsequent or continuation of the offence, the medical practitioner\u2019s\nregistration can be suspended for a period of five years.<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">An\nintending couple who seeks the aid of any surrogacy clinic or registered\nmedical practitioner for commercial surrogacy shall be punishable with\nimprisonment of five years and with a fine of Rs 5 lakh for the first offence;\nfor subsequent offence the imprisonment may extend to 10 years and fine to Rs\n10 lakh.<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Every\noffence under the Act shall be cognisable, non-bailable and non-compoundable.<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; It has no artificial flavors or harmful components. , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All women who might\nbecome pregnant should consume folic acid supplements to help prevent neural\ntube defects in babies, &nbsp;and &nbsp;reduce the risk of Down syndrome.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Citrus fruits, such as\norange juice.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Beans.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Papaya &nbsp;( NOT GM )<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cereals.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rice. ( GM RICE GIVES\nNO PROTECTION ) <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Also known as vitamin\nB9, folic acid helps the body perform many essential functions, including\nnucleotide biosynthesis in cells, DNA synthesis and repair, red blood cell\ncreation, and prevention of anemia.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Folic acid also encourages normal fetal\ndevelopment. In fact, folic acid, calcium, and iron have long been considered\nthe holy trinity of prenatal wellness.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;A deficiency of the vitamin in pregnant women\ncan have significant negative effects on unborn children\u2019s brain development.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is a link between\nthe Down syndrome and neural tube defects, and folic acid supplements may be an\neffective way to prevent both.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc;
